title: How to use my mobile phone to connect via satellite - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A Can I turn my cell phone into a satellite phone? No. 30 years ago it wasn’t impossible that some “genius” could take a radio apart and reassemble the parts into something else. 50 years ago you could re-tune a radio to a different band by rewinding a coil. Now, modern electronics is so integrated that you can’t really do anything without special equipment, and mobile phones are among the most highly integrated and dense devices there are. If you can’t do it in software you can’t do it, and it’s not possible to reprogram the radio chips as far as I know. There’s something called Software-defined radio but I’m pretty sure you can’t use that on a phone to communicate with a satellite. How can I use my mobile phone to connect via satellite? I have an older Garmin inReach satellite communicator. That lets me send texts via a clunky ABCD soft keyboard one letter at a time. It also has a Bluetooth interface, and with an app on my phone I can use the phone QWERTY keyboard to send messages a bit easier, and read them on a bigger screen than the tiny one on the inReach. It’s not a real internet connection so I can’t use a web browser, though, and the message charges are hugely more than on a phone. Per Starlink (satellite constellation) - Wikipedia the upcoming internet satellites won’t communicate directly with mobile phones; you’d have a satellite transceiver and a wifi router the same as you have at home.

I’ve personally come across a number of people who think that their mobile phone is interacting with satellites in space, and therefore I imagine that it must be quite a widely held belief.  I am afraid that this is untrue. Mobile phones communicate with ground-based cell towers that are probably 100 to 1000 metres away from where you are standing. When the cell tower receives the signal from your phone, it then sends the voice signals onward to other phones (and other phone companies) through wires.  Perhaps if you make an international call, then at some point your signal gets bounced via a satellite, although there are many undersea cables crossing the Atlantic and Pacific oceans. If your call gets sent via satellite, this has nothing directly to do with your mobile phone; it is only to do with a decision by the phone company about how they will route their voice traffic. Your mobile phone has no ability (either in its hardware or software) to send and receive signals directly to/from a satellite in space.

As others have said: your phone cannot directly communicate with a satellite. Neither your phone, nor the satellite are designed for that. However you can buy adaptors which allow your phone to communicate via satellite. There is a device called Iridium Go which is an Iridium satellite access point:https://www.iridium.com/products/details/iridiumgoThere is also an iPhone satphone cover I believe.

There is technically one way to connect to a satellite with your phone. Amateur radio satellites such as the International Space Station have packet radio on board. Using a program called APRSDroid you can connect an amateur radio transceiver to your phone and use the aprsdroid app to connect to the satellite, of course you need a license for this.

You can't.  Your mobile phone is not able to operate on the correct frequencies, and does not have the right type of antenna. There are specialized satellite phone handsets to do this that enable communications from virtually anywhere on the planet.

The only way to do this is to have a satellite mobile phone like iridium /thuraya because simply in that case that phone is connected to a group of satellites owned by a company like iridium /thuraya and of course it,s not gonna work with normal cell networks Iridium Satellite Communications https://www.thuraya.com/
